children.name: burn
children.definition: to damage or destroy sth with fire or heat:đốt cháy (cái gì )
examples: She lit a fire and burned his letters one by one.
burn a hole in sthmake a hole by burning it:
Someone had dropped a cigarette and burned a hole in the carpet.
burn sth to a crisp/cinderdestroy sth completely by burning it : đốt cái gì thành tro
Most of his possessions had been burnt to a cinder.
be badly/severely burnedHis face had been badly burned in the fire.
be burned aliveThe animals were burned alive when a farm building caught fire.
be burned to deathAnyone inside the truck would have been burned to death.
be burned to the groundThe Grand Hotel hadburnt to the ground.
be burned at the stake(= burned in a fire as a punishment )In those days witches were burned at the stake.
burnt/ burned[adj]bị đốt, bị cháy
The cake is slightly burnt, I’m afraid.

children.name: burn down
children.definition: to completelydestroyabuildingby burning it: đốt sập ( tòa nhà )
examples: burn down sth/ burn sth down
Police believe students are responsible for burning down the school.
Her ex-husband threatened to burn the house down with her and the kids inside.

children.name: scorch
children.definition: to burn thesurfaceof sth and leave adarkmarkon it:làm cháy sém
examples: The heater was left on all night and it scorched the wall.
Having the iron on a very high heat can scorch the fabric.
scorch mark[C]vết cháy xém
This shirt is ruined - there’s a big scorch mark on the back.

children.name: incinerate
children.definition: to destroyunwantedthingsby burning them in aspecialmachine: đốt cháy (vật bỏ đi bằng máy chuyên dụng)
examples: Household waste is usually incinerated after it has been collected.
All the clothes that were affected by radiation had to be incinerated.

children.name: singe
children.definition: to damage sth such as hair, wool, or paper by burning itslightlyso that theendsoredgesare burnt:làm cháy xém
examples: The flames were hot enough to singe your eyebrows.
The rug was singed by a piece of burning coal that had fallen from the fire.

children.name: charred
children.definition: wood, sticks, bones etc that are charred areblackbecause they have been damaged by burning:đã hóa than
examples: In the cave they found some charred animal bones.
It was nearly impossible to recognize the charred bodies.

children.name: burn up
children.definition: if sth is burnt up, it is completely destroyed by fire or heat :
examples: Most of the woodland has now been burnt up.

children.name: burn
children.definition: if you burn yourself, you hurt yourself byaccidentallytouching sth hot:làm bỏng (chạm vào cái gì nóng)
examples: burn yourself: bị bỏng
Don’t touch the iron. You’ll burn yourself.
burn your mouth/fingers/arm etc
She burnt her arm on a camping stove.
be badly/severely/seriously burned/burnt: bị bỏng nặng / nghiêm trọng
Jerry was badly burned in the explosion Jerry
burn[C noun] a mark on your skin where you have been burned:vết bỏng, vết cháy, vết bỏng
The child had cigarette burns on his arms and legs.
severe/serious burns
Billy was taken to the hospital with severe burns.
minor burnsnot serious:
Jones suffered only minor burns when her house was set ablaze last week.

children.name: scald
children.definition: to burn yourself with very hotliquidorsteam:làm bỏng (bởi chất lỏng hay hơi nước)
examples: scald yourself:bị bỏng
If you’re not careful you’ll scald yourself on/with that kettle.
scald your arm/leg/hand etc
The hot coffee nearly scalded his tongue.

children.name: burn
children.definition: to produce flames and heat:(cái gì) cháy
examples: A pile of branches was burning in the yard.
At one end of the room a coal fire burned brightly.
The candle flickered briefly, then burned with a steady flame.
burning[attri adj] [B1]đang bốc cháy
The smell of burning rubber filled the air.
He was 200 yards from the burning ship when it exploded.

children.name: be on fire
children.definition: if abuilding, vehicle etcis on fire, it is burning:đang cháy
examples: Large areas of the forest are reported to be on fire.
Before long the neighboring houses were on fire too.
If your home was on fire and you could save only one thing, what would it be?

children.name: blazing
children.definition: burning verybrightlywith a lot of flames and heat:đang rực cháy
examples: They sat on the sofa in front of a blazing fire.
The heat from the blazing car could be felt several metres away.

children.name: smolder
children.definition: smoulder /  to burnslowly, producingsmokebutnoflames:âm ỉ cháy
examples: The fire in the chemical factory was so intense that it was still smouldering a week later.
A cigarette smoldered in the ashtray.
a pile of smoldering leaves.
smoulderingembers

children.name: be in flames
children.definition: /beablaze to be on fire with a lot of flames, causingseriousdamage:ngập trong lửa
examples: When the fire department arrived the whole school was in flames.
Twelve hours after the bombing raid, many parts of the city were still ablaze.

children.name: flicker
children.definition: if a fire or flame flickers, it burnsunsteadily:cháy lập lòe, bập bùng
examples: A welcoming fire flickered in the grate.
Inside the shrine candles flicker next to statues of saints.

children.name: flammable
children.definition: /inflammablematerials, chemicals, or gasesthat are flammable or inflammable will start burning very easily and quickly, so they can bedangerous:dễ bén lửa, dễ cháy
examples: The report stated that inflammable substances were found near the building’s heating system.
highlyinflammable/flammableextremely flammable:
Hydrogen is a highly flammable gas.

children.name: burn
children.definition: to be able to be burned:dễ đốt, dễ cháy
examples: Does styrofoam burn?
burn well/easily/badly etc
Hard woods generally don’t burn well.

children.name: catch fire
children.definition: especially US  to start burningaccidentally:bắt lửa, bốc cháy
examples: Two farm workers died when a barn caught fire yesterday.
The car turned over, but luckily it didn’t catch fire.
There was an explosion, and the whole garage caught on fire.

children.name: burst into flames
children.definition: burstintoflames tosuddenlystart burning and produce a lot of flames that causeseriousdamage :bốc cháy,bùng cháy
examples: The plane crashed into the side of the mountain and burst into flames.
Without warning the toaster burst into flames.

children.name: break out
children.definition: if afirebreaks out, it starts burningaccidentallyandspreadsveryquickly:(ngọn lửa) bùng cháy (và lan đi rất nhanh)
examples: Over £20,000 worth of damage was caused when a fire broke out in the cellar.
Would you know what to do if a fire broke out in your school?

children.name: go up
children.definition: (in flames) if abuildingorvehiclegoes up or goes up in flames, it starts burning veryquicklyand usually isdestroyedby fire:bốc cháy
examples: Be careful with those matches, or the whole place will go up in flames!
The fire spread slowly until it reached the gas cylinders, then the factory went up in flames.
If the oil tanker goes up, it could burn for weeks.

children.name: flare up
children.definition: tosuddenlybegin to burn, or suddenly burn muchmorestrongly than before, with a strong, bright flame:bùng cháy (bắt đầu cháy hay cháy mạnh hơn )
examples: The spilled gasoline suddenly flared up in a sheet of flame.
They threw some dry wood onto the bonfire and it flared up, showering sparks into the night sky.

children.name: ignite
children.definition: to start burning:bốc cháy
examples: Scientists could not explain why the gas had suddenly ignited.
The compound ignites at 450 degrees Celsius.

children.name: burn down
children.definition: if a building burns down, it is completely destroyed by fire :(tòa nhà) cháy sập
examples: Charlene has lived with relatives since her house burned down.
The hotel burnt down in 1990.

children.name: gutted
children.definition: abuildingthat is gutted isstillstanding, but its inside has been completely destroyed by fire:bị cháy rụi
examples: ‘Was there anything worth saving after the fire?’
‘No, the place is completely gutted.’
a street full of gutted buildings
gut[T verb]đốt trụi
A blaze gutted the dance hall last April.

children.name: burnt-out
children.definition: mainly UK /burned-outmainly US  abuildingor avehiclethat is burnt-out or burned-out has had everything inside it destroyed by fire:bị cháy rụi
examples: In the main square the burnt-out shell of the Palace of Justice still smouldered.
The van was burned-out and completely blackened by smoke.
After the fire the factory was completely burnt-out/just a burnt-out shell.

children.name: burn up
children.definition: if sth burns up, it is completely destroyed by fire or heat :
examples: The satellite will burn up as it re-enters the Earth’s atmosphere.
Meteorites often burn up in the atmosphere before they reach the Earth.

children.name: sth that does not burn easily
fireproof
children.definition: not easily damaged by flames:chống lửa/chống cháy
examples: Theatre curtains have to be fireproof.

children.name: flameproof
children.definition: / flame-resistantclothesorsubstancessuch as glass that are flameproof or flame-resistant have been specially made so that they are not damaged by fire:chống lửa/chống cháy
examples: Heat the mixture in a flameproof dish.
Children’s pajamas are usually made from flame-resistant material.
